''Colloquial Cambodian: a complete language course''. London: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-10006-2}} * Stewart, F., & May, S. (2004). ''In the shadow of Angkor: contemporary writing from Cambodia''. Honolulu: University of Hawai'i Press. {{ISBN|0-8248-2849-6}} * Tonkin, D. (1991). ''The Cambodian alphabet: how to write the Khmer language''. Bangkok: Trasvin Publications. {{ISBN|974-88670-2-1}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{InterWiki|code=km}} {{Commons category}} * [[voy:Khmer phrasebook|Khmer phrasebook]] from [[Wikivoyage]] * [http://kheng.info/ Kheng.info]—An online audio dictionary for learning Khmer, with thousands of native speaker recordings and [http://kheng.info/word_segmentation/ text segmentation software]. * [http://www.languagelinksdatabase.com/cambodian-khmer/ Language Links Database – language links and resources for Khmer language] * [http://sealang.net/mk/khmeric.htm SEAlang Project: Mon–Khmer languages. The Khmeric Branch] * [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Khmer_Swadesh_list Khmer Swadesh vocabulary list] (from Wiktionary's [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Swadesh_lists Swadesh-list appendix]) * [https://code.google.com/p/khmer-dictionary-tools/ Dictionary and SpellChecker] open sourced and collaborative project based on [[Chuon Nath]] Khmer Dictionary * [http://www.sbbic.org/lang/en-us/2010/07/15/how-to-install-khmer-unicode-on-windows-7/ How to install Khmer script on a Windows 7 computer] * [http://www.sbbic.org/lang/en-us/2010/03/27/how-to-install-khmer-unicode-on-your-windows-xp-computer How to install Khmer script on a Windows XP computer] * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20101230070221/http://www.lmp.ucla.edu/Profile.aspx?menu=004&LangID=75 Khmer]'' at [https://web.archive.org/web/20060720065425/http://www.pavelicpapers.com/documents/odpor/index.html UCLA Language Materials project] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110821053921/http://dict.ant.com.kh/dictionaries/ Online Khmer & English dictionary] * [http://dictionary.tovnah.com/ Khmer Online Dictionaries] * [[wikiotics:km/Khmer lessons|Khmer audio lessons at Wikiotics]] * http://unicode-table.com/en/sections/khmer/ * http://unicode-table.com/en/sections/khmer-symbols/ {{Languages of Cambodia}} {{Languages of Thailand}} {{Languages of Vietnam}} {{Austroasiatic languages}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Languages attested from the 9th century]] [[Category:Analytic languages]] [[Category:Isolating languages]] [[Category:Khmer language| ]] [[Category:Languages of Cambodia]] [[Category:Languages of Thailand]] [[Category:Languages of Vietnam]] [[Category:Subject–verb–object languages]]

revision.text:
{{Languages of | country = [[Netherlands]] | official = [[Dutch language|Dutch]] (>90%) | regional = Official: [[West Frisian language|West Frisian]] (2.50%),{{cite web|url=http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0027230/geldigheidsdatum_28-10-2014|title=Regeling - Instellingsbesluit Consultatief Orgaan Fries 2010 - BWBR0027230|website=wetten.overheid.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} [[English language|English]] ([[BES Islands]]),{{cite web|url=http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0028063/|title=wetten.nl - Regeling - Invoeringswet openbare lichamen Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba - BWBR0028063|website=Wetten.overheid.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} [[Papiamento]] ([[Bonaire]]);{{cite web|url=http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0028142/HoofdstukIII/AfdelingVI/2/Artikel111/geldigheidsdatum_28-10-2014|title=Regeling - Wet openbare lichamen Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba - BWBR0028142|website=Wetten.overheid.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} Not official: [[Dutch Low Saxon]] (10.9%){{cite web|url=http://taal.phileon.nl/nedersaksisch.php|title=Taal in Nederland .:. Nedersaksisch|website=taal.phileon.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} [[Limburgish]] (4.50%) | immigrant = [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] (2%), [[Varieties of Arabic]] (1.5%), [[Turkish language|Turkish]] (1.5%), [[Berber languages]] (1%) See further: [[Demographics of the Netherlands#Migration|Immigration to the Netherlands]] | foreign = [[English language|English]] (90%) (excluding the BES Islands)
[[German language|German]] (71%), [[French language|French]] (29%), [[Spanish language|Spanish]] (5%){{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_386_en.pdf|title=EUROPEANS AND THEIR LANGUAGES|date=6 January 2016|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=23 August 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106183351/http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_386_en.pdf|archivedate=6 January 2016|df=}} | sign = [[Dutch Sign Language]] | keyboard = US international QWERTY | keyboard image = [[Image:KB US-International.svg|200px]] }} {{Life in the Netherlands}} {{Dutch dialects}} [[File:Foreign languages Netherlands, 2005.png|thumb|right|275px|Knowledge of foreign languages in the Netherlands, in percent of the population over 15, 2006. Data taken from an EU survey.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_386_en.pdf|format=PDF|title=EUROPEANS AND THEIR LANGUAGES|website=Ec.europa.eu|accessdate=2017-08-23}}]] [[File:Knowledge German Netherlands 2005.png|thumb|right|275px|Knowledge of the German language in the Netherlands, 2005. According to the Eurobarometer: 70% of the respondents indicated that they know German well enough to have a conversation. Of these 12% (per cent, not percentage points) reported a very good knowledge of the language whereas 22% had a good knowledge and 43% basic German skills.]] The [[official language]] of [[the Netherlands]] is [[Dutch language|Dutch]], spoken by almost all people in the Netherlands. Dutch is also spoken and official in [[Aruba]], [[Bonaire]], [[Belgium]], [[Curaçao]], [[Saba]], [[Sint Maarten]] and [[Suriname]]. It is a [[West Germanic languages|West Germanic]], [[Low Franconian]] language that originated in the Early Middle Ages (c. 470) and was standardised in the 16th century. There are also some recognised provincial languages and regional dialects. *[[West Frisian language|West Frisian]] is a co-official language in the [[provinces of the Netherlands|province]] of [[Friesland]]. West Frisian is spoken by 453,000 speakers.{{cite web|url=http://taal.phileon.nl/fries.php|title=Taal in Nederland .:. Fries|website=taal.phileon.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} *[[English language|English]] is an official language in the special municipalities of [[Saba]] and [[Sint Eustatius]] ([[BES Islands]]), as well as the autonomous states of [[Curaçao]] and [[Sint Maarten]]. It is widely spoken on Saba and Sint Eustatius (see also: [[English language in the Netherlands]]). On Saba and St. Eustatius, the majority of the education is in English only, with some bilingual English-Dutch schools. *[[Papiamento]] is an official language in the special municipality of [[Bonaire]]. It is also the native language in the autonomous states of [[Curaçao]] and [[Aruba]]. *[[Low Saxon dialects in the Netherlands|Several dialects]] of [[Dutch Low Saxon]] (''Nederlands Nedersaksisch'' in Dutch) are spoken in much of the north-east of the country and are recognised as regional languages according to the [[European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages]]. Low Saxon is spoken by 1,798,000 speakers. *Another Low Franconian dialect is [[Limburgish]], which is spoken in the south-eastern province of [[Limburg (Netherlands)|Limburg]]. [[Limburgish]] is spoken by 825,000 speakers. Though there are movements to have Limburgish recognised as an official language (meeting with varying amounts of success,) it is important to note that Limburgish in fact consists of a large number of differing dialects that share some common aspects, but are quite different.{{cite web|url=http://taal.phileon.nl/lim_situatie.php|title=Taal in Nederland .:. Limburgs|website=taal.phileon.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} However, both [[West Low German|Low Saxon]] and [[Limburgish]] spread across the Dutch-German border and belong to a common Dutch-[[German language|German]] [[dialect continuum]]. The Netherlands also has its separate [[Dutch Sign Language]], called ''Nederlandse Gebarentaal'' (NGT). It is still waiting for recognition and has 17,500 users.Rapport "Meer dan een gebaar" en "actualisatie 1997-2001 There is a trend of learning foreign languages in the Netherlands: between 90% and 93%{{cite web|url=https://alisonedwardsdotcom.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/phd-thesis_edwards.pdf|title="English in the Netherlands: Functions, forms and attitudes" p. 316 and onwards|website=Alisonedwardsdotcom.files.wordpress.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}} of the total population are able to converse in [[English language|English]], 71% in [[German language|German]], 29% in [[French language|French]] and 5% in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. == Minority languages, regional languages and dialects in the Benelux == === West Frisian dialects === [[West Frisian language|West Frisian]] is an official language in the Dutch province of [[Friesland]] (''Fryslân'' in West Frisian). The government of the Frisian province is bilingual. Since 1996 West Frisian has been recognised as an official minority language in the [[Netherlands]] under the [[European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages]], although it had been recognised by the Dutch government as the second state language (''tweede rijkstaal''), with official status in Friesland, since the 1950s. * [[West Frisian language|Westlauwers Frisian]] **[[Wood Frisian]] **[[Clay Frisian]] **[[Noordhoeks]] **[[Zuidwesthoeks]] **[[Hindeloopers]] **[[Westers]] **[[Aasters]] **[[Schiermonnikoogs]] === Low Saxon dialects === * [[Gronings]]-[[East Frisian Low Saxon|East Frisian]] **[[Kollumerpompsters]] **[[Hoogelandsters]] **[[Oldambtsters]] **[[Westerwolds]] **[[Veenkoloniaals]] **[[Stadsgronings]] **[[Noordenvelds]] (Noord-Drents) *[[Westerkwartiers]] * [[Midden-Drents]] * [[Zuid-Drents]] * [[Stellingwerfs]] * [[Gelders-Overijssels|Guelderish-Overijssels]] **[[Urkers|Urkish]] **[[Sallands]] **[[Achterhoeks]] *[[Twents]] **Oost-Twents ** [[Vriezenveens]] (this is actually a separate dialect because of West Frisian influences) * [[Twents-Graafschaps]] * [[Veluws]] **Oost-Veluws **West-Veluws [[Image:Languages Benelux.PNG|right|thumb|400px|Minority languages, regional languages and dialects in the [[Benelux]] countries]] === Low Franconian dialects === * [[West Frisian (dialect)|West Frisian]] ** Mainland West Frisian ** Insular West Frisian ** [[Stadsfries]] ** Midlands ** Amelands ** Bildts * [[Hollandic]] ** Kennemerlandic ** Zaans ** Waterlandic ** Amsterdams ** Strand-Hollands ** Haags ** Rotterdams ** Utrechts-Alblasserwaards ** Westhoeks * [[Zealandic]]-[[West Flemish]] (including [[French Flemish]]) ** Zealandic ** Burger-Zeeuws ** Coastal West Flemish ** Continental West Flemish * [[East Flemish]] [[File:Rheinischer faecher.png|thumb|400px|'''The Rhinelandic dialect continuum'''
—— ''[[Low Franconian languages|Low Franconian]] ([[Dutch language|Dutch]])'' —— {{legend|yellow|(1) [[Brabantian]] (incl. [[South Guelderish]], [[East Bergish]])}}{{legend|lightgreen|(2) [[Limburgish language|Limburgish]] (incl. most of [[Bergish dialects|Bergish]])}}—— ''[[West Central German]] ([[Central Franconian dialects|Central]] and [[Rhine Franconian dialects|Rhine Franconian]])'' —— {{legend|lightblue|(3) [[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian]] (incl. [[South Bergish]])}}{{legend|blue|(4), (5) [[Moselle Franconian dialects|Moselle Franconian]] (incl. [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]])}}{{legend|violet|(6) [[Rhine Franconian dialects|Rhine Franconian]]}}]] * [[Zuid-Gelders|South Guelderish]] (Kleverlands) **Rivierenlands **Liemers **Nijmeegs **North Limburgian * [[Brabantian]] **Northwest Brabantian **Central north Brabantian **East Brabantian **Kempen Brabantian **South Brabantian * [[Limburgish]] **West Limburgish **Central Limburgish **Southeast Limburgish **[[Low Dietsch]] === Central Franconian dialects === *[[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian]] **[[Kerkrade dialect]]{{cite web|url=http://www.kerkrade.nl/de_stad_kerkrade/kerkrade_toen_en_nu/kirchroadsj_plat|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221111356/http://www.kerkrade.nl/de_stad_kerkrade/kerkrade_toen_en_nu/kirchroadsj_plat|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 February 2015|title=Gemeente Kerkrade - Kirchröadsj Plat|website=www.kerkrade.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} **[[Vaals dialect]]{{cite web|url=http://www.vaals.nl/voor-inwoners/cittaslow-gemeente_3683/|title=Cittaslow Vaals: verrassend, veelzijdig, veelkleurig|accessdate=9 September 2015}} The PDF file can be accessed at the bottom of the page. The relevant citation is on the page 13: "De enige taal waarin Vaals echt te beschrijven en te bezingen valt is natuurlijk het Völser dialect. Dit dialect valt onder het zogenaamde Ripuarisch." Note that Ripuarian is not recognised as a regional language of the Netherlands. === Dialects fully outside the Netherlands === [[Luxembourgish]] is divided into Moselle Luxembourgish, West Luxembourgish, East Luxembourgish, North Luxembourgish and City Luxembourgish.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} The [[Oïl dialects]] in the Benelux are [[Walloon language|Walloon]] (divided into West Walloon, Central Walloon, East Walloon and South Walloon), [[Lorrain language|Lorrain]] (including Gaumais), [[Champenois]] and [[Picard language|Picard]] (including Tournaisis). ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{Reflist}} ===Notations=== *{{cite web|url=http://taal.phileon.nl/fries.php|title=Taal in Nederland .:. Fries|website=taal.phileon.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} *{{cite web|url=http://taal.phileon.nl/nedersaksisch.php|title=Taal in Nederland .:. Nedersaksisch|website=taal.phileon.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} *{{cite web|url=http://taal.phileon.nl/lim_situatie.php|title=Taal in Nederland .:. Limburgs|website=taal.phileon.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}} {{Refbegin}} *{{cite web|last=Ginsburgh |first=Victor |authorlink= |author2=Ignacio Ortuño-Ortin |author3=Shlomo Weber |title=Why Do People Learn Foreign Languages? |work= |publisher=Université libre de Bruxelles |date=February 2005 |url=http://bib17.ulb.ac.be:8080/dspace/bitstream/2013/1957/1/vg-0155.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025011303/http://bib17.ulb.ac.be:8080/dspace/bitstream/2013/1957/1/vg-0155.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-25 |format=pdf |doi= |accessdate=2007-10-10 |df= }} - specifically, see Table 2. {{Refend}} {{Languages of the Netherlands}} {{Languages of the Benelux}} {{Netherlands topics}} {{Languages of Europe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Languages Of The Netherlands}} [[Category:Languages of the Netherlands|*]]

revision.comment: Added a few new forms
revision.text:
{{about||details about the types and origin of irregular verbs in English|English irregular verbs|verbs generally|English verbs}} This is a list of [[irregular verbs]] in the [[English language]].
==Past tense irregular verbs==
For each verb listed, the [[citation form]] (the bare [[infinitive]]) is given first, with a link to the relevant [[Wiktionary]] entry. This is followed by the [[simple past]] tense ([[preterite]]), and then the [[past participle]]. If there are irregular [[present tense]] forms (see [[#Present tense irregular verbs|below]]), these are given in parentheses after the infinitive. (The [[present participle]] and [[gerund]] forms of verbs, ending in ''[[-ing]]'', are always regular. In English, these are used as verbs, adjectives, and nouns.) In the case of [[English modal verbs|modal verbs]] the present and preterite forms are listed, since these are the only forms that exist.
The right-hand column notes whether the verb is [[Germanic weak verb|weak]] or [[Germanic strong verb|strong]] and whether it belongs to a subclass, and links to descriptions elsewhere. Information about the development of these verbs generally can be found at [[English irregular verbs]]; details of the etymology and usage of specific verbs can be found by consulting Wiktionary.
In some cases, there are two or more possibilities for a given form. In the table, the preferred or more common usage is generally listed first, though for some words the usage is nearly equal for the two choices. Sometimes the usage depends on the [[American and British English differences|dialect]]. In many cases, such as ''spell'' (''spelt'' vs. ''spelled''), ''learn'' (''learnt'' vs. ''learned''), and ''spill'' (''spilt'' vs. ''spilled''), [[American English]] normally uses the regular form, while [[British English]] tends to favor the irregular. In other cases, such as ''dive'' (''dived'' vs. ''dove'') and ''sneak'' (''sneaked'' vs. ''snuck''), the opposite is true. [[Australian English|Australian]], [[New Zealand English|New Zealand]] and [[South African English]] tend to follow the British practice, while [[Canadian English]] often sides with the American usage.
The table includes selected archaic or dialectal forms, marked * (some of these forms may survive in specialist uses).
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! Verb forms !! Verb class and notes |- valign="top" | ''[[wikt:ache|ache]]/*ake – ached/*oke – ached/*aken'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 6|Strong, class 6]]; now regular. |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bake|bake]] – baked/*book – baked/*baken'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 6|Strong, class 6]]; now regular except in Northern English dialects. |-valign=top | ''[[wikt:be|be]] (am, is, are) – was, were – been'' | [[Suppletive]]. See [[Indo-European copula]]. |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bear|bear]] – bore/*bare – borne/born'' :''[[wikt:forbear|forbear]] – forbore/*forbare – forborne/forborn'' :''[[wikt:misbear|*misbear]] – *misbore/*misbare – *misborne/misborn'' :''[[wikt:overbear|overbear]] – overbore/*overbare – overborne/overborn'' :''[[wikt:underbear|underbear]] – underbore/*underbare – underborne/underborn'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 4|Strong, class 4]]. The spelling ''born'' is used in [[English passive voice|passive]] or [[verbal adjective|adjectival]] contexts relating to [[birth]]. |-valign=top |''[[wikt:beat|beat]] – beat – beaten/beat'' :''[[wikt:browbeat|browbeat]] – browbeat – browbeaten/browbeat'' :''[[wikt:overbeat|overbeat]] – overbeat – overbeaten/overbeat'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 7|Strong, class 7]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:become|become]] – became – become'' :''[[wikt:misbecome|misbecome]] – misbecame – misbecome'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 4|Strong, class 4]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:beget|*beget]] – begot/*begat – begot/begotten'' :''[[wikt:misbeget|misbeget]] – misbegot/*misbegat – misbegotten/misbegot'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 5|Strong, class 5]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:begin|begin]] – began – begun'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bend|bend]] – bent/*bended – bent/*bended'' :''[[wikt:overbend|overbend]] – overbent/*overbended – overbent/*overbended'' :''[[wikt:unbend|unbend]] – unbent/*unbended – unbent/*unbended'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:beseech|beseech]] – beseeched/*besought – beseeched/*besought'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with ''[[Rückumlaut]]'' and [[Germanic spirant law]] (now regularized) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bet|bet]] – bet/betted – bet/betted'' :''[[wikt:underbet|underbet]] – underbet/underbetted – underbet/underbetted'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:betide|betide]] – betided/*betid – betided/*betid'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with vowel shortening and coalescence of dentals (or regular) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:beware#English|beware]] – ''(no other forms) | [[Defective verb|Defective]]; formed from ''be'' with predicate adjective, used as infinitive, imperative and subjunctive only. Inflected forms (''bewares'', ''bewared'', ''bewaring'') are considered obsolete. |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bid|bid]] ''[in auctions etc.]'' – bid – bid'' :''[[wikt:outbid|outbid]] – outbid – outbid'' :''[[wikt:overbid|overbid]] – overbid – overbid'' :''[[wikt:rebid|rebid]] – rebid – rebid'' :''[[wikt:underbid|underbid]] – underbid – underbid'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bid|bid]] ''[meaning to request or say]'' – bid/*bade – bid/*bidden'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 5|Strong, class 5]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bide|bide]] – bided/bode – bided/bidden'' :''[[wikt:abide|abide]] – abided/*abode – abided/*abidden'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 1|Strong, class 1]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bind|bind]] – bound – bound/*bounden'' :''[[wikt:unbind|unbind]] – unbound – unbound/*unbounden'' :''[[wikt:underbind|underbind]] – underbound – underbound/*underbounden'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bite|bite]] – bit – bitten'' :''[[wikt:frostbite|frostbite]] – frostbit – frostbitten'' |[[Germanic strong verb#Class 1|Strong, class 1]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bleed|bleed]] – bled – bled'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with vowel shortening and coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:blend|blend]] – blended/*blent – blended/*blent'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with devoiced ending (or regular) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bless|bless]] – blessed/*blest – blessed/*blest'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]], regular with alternative (archaic) spelling |-valign=top |''[[wikt:blow|blow]] – blew – blown'' :''[[wikt:overblow|overblow]] – overblew – overblown'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 7|Strong, class 7]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:break|break]] – broke/*brake – broken/*broke'' :''[[wikt:outbreak|outbreak]] – outbroke – outbroken'' :''[[wikt:rebreak|rebreak]] – rebroke – rebroken'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 4|Strong, class 4]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:breed|breed]] – bred – bred'' :''[[wikt:inbreed|inbreed]] – inbred – inbred'' :''[[wikt:interbreed|interbreed]] – interbred – interbred'' :''[[wikt:overbreed|overbreed]] – overbred – overbred'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with vowel shortening and coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bring|bring]] – brought – brought'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with ''[[Rückumlaut]]'' and [[Germanic spirant law]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:build|build]] – built – built'' :''[[wikt:overbuild|overbuild]] – overbuilt – overbuilt'' :''[[wikt:rebuild|rebuild]] – rebuilt – rebuilt'' :''[[wikt:underbuild|underbuild]] – underbuilt – underbuilt'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals and devoiced ending |-valign=top |''[[wikt:burn|burn]] – burned/burnt – burned/burnt'' :''[[wikt:sunburn|sunburn]] – sunburned/sunburnt – sunburned/sunburnt | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with devoiced ending (or regular) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:burst|burst]] – burst/*brast – burst/*bursten'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:bust|bust]] – busted/bust – busted/bust'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] (or regular) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:buy|buy]] – bought – bought/*boughten'' :''[[wikt:abuy|*abuy]] – *abought – *abought :''[[wikt:overbuy|overbuy]] – overbought – overbought'' :''[[wikt:underbuy|underbuy]] – underbought – underbought'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with ''[[Rückumlaut]]'' and [[Germanic spirant law]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:can|can]] ''[auxiliary verb]'' – could – ''(none) | [[Preterite-present (In the meaning of roast on a [[spit roast|spit]], the verb is regular.) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:split|split]] – split – split'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:spoil|spoil]] – spoiled/spoilt – spoiled/spoilt'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with devoiced ending (or regular) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:spread|spread]] – spread/*spreaded – spread/*spreaded'' :''[[wikt:bespread|*bespread]] – bespread/*bespreaded – bespread/*bespreaded'' :''[[wikt:forspread|*forspread]] – forspread – forspread'' :''[[wikt:outspread|outspread]] – outspread – outspread'' :''[[wikt:overspread|overspread]] – overspread – overspread'' :''[[wikt:underspread|underspread]] – underspread – underspread'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:spring|spring]] – sprang/sprung – sprung/*sprang'' :''[[wikt:handspring|handspring]] – handsprang/handsprung – handsprung/*handsprang'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:stand|stand]] – stood – stood/*standen'' :''[[wikt:forstand|forstand]] – forstood – forstood/*forstanden'' :''[[wikt:misunderstand|misunderstand]] – misunderstood – misunderstood/*misunderstanden'' :''[[wikt:overstand|overstand]] – overstood – overstood/*overstanden'' :''[[wikt:understand|understand]] – understood – understood/*understanden'' :''[[wikt:upstand|upstand]] – upstood – upstood/*upstanden'' :''[[wikt:withstand|withstand]] – withstood – withstood/*withstanden'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 6|Strong, class 6]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:starve|starve]] – starved/*starf/*storve – starved/*storven'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:stave|stave]] – stove/staved – stove/staved/*stoven'' | Originally weak; irregular forms developed by analogy with strong verbs.<ref>The forms ''stove'' and ''stoven'' are found from the 18th century onward. See ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', Second Edition, entry for "stave".</ref> |-valign=top |''[[wikt:stay|stay]] – stayed/*staid – stayed/*staid'' | Regular, with alternative spelling ''staid'' (now limited to certain [[deverbal adjective|adjectival]] uses) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:steal|steal]] – stole – stolen'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 4|Strong, class 4]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:stick|stick]] – stuck/*sticked – stuck/*sticked'' | Originally weak, irregular forms by analogy with strong verbs |-valign=top |''[[wikt:sting|sting]] – stung/*stang – stung'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:stink|stink]] – stank/stunk – stunk'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:stretch|stretch]] – stretched/*straught/*straight – stretched/*straught/*straight'' | Weak, now regular; obsolete past form ''straught'' as with ''teach–taught'' |-valign=top |''[[wikt:strew|strew]] – strewed – strewn/strewed'' :''[[wikt:bestrew|bestrew]] – bestrewed – bestrewn/bestrewed'' :''[[wikt:overstrew|overstrew]] – overstrewed – overstrewn/overstrewed'' | Originally weak, irregular forms by analogy with strong verbs |-valign=top |''[[wikt:stride|stride]] – strode/*strided – stridden/*strode/*strid/*stridded'' :''[[wikt:bestride|bestride]] – bestrode/*bestrided – bestridden/*bestrode/*bestrid/*bestridded'' :''[[wikt:outstride|outstride]] – outstrode/*outstrided – outstridden/*outstrode/*outstrid/*outstridded'' :''[[wikt:overstride|overstride]] – overstrode/*overstrided – overstridden/*overstrode/*overstrid/*overstridded'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 1|Strong, class 1]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:strike|strike]] – struck – struck/stricken'' :''[[wikt:overstrike|overstrike]] – overstruck – overstruck/overstricken'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 1|Strong, class 1]]. The form ''stricken'' is limited to certain [[deverbal adjective|adjectival]] and specialist uses. |-valign=top |''[[wikt:string|string]] – strung/*stringed – strung/*stringed'' :''[[wikt:hamstring|hamstring]] – hamstrung/*hamstringed – hamstrung/*hamstringed'' :''[[wikt:overstring|overstring]] – overstrung/*overstringed – overstrung/*overstringed'' | Originally [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|weak]], irregular forms developed by analogy with strong verbs |-valign=top |''[[wikt:strip|strip]] – stripped/stript – stripped/stript'' | |-valign=top |''[[wikt:strive|strive]] – strove/strived – striven/strived'' :''[[wikt:outstrive|outstrive]] – outstrove – outstriven'' :''[[wikt:overstrive|overstrive]] – overstrove – overstriven'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 1|Strong, class 1]] (or regularized) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:swear|swear]] – swore – sworn'' :''[[wikt:forswear|forswear]] – forswore – forsworn'' :''[[wikt:outswear|outswear]] – outswore – outsworn'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 6|Strong, class 6]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:sweat|sweat]] – sweated/sweat – sweated/sweat'' | Weak, usually regular, possible past form ''sweat'' with coalescence of dentals |-valign=top |''[[wikt:sweep|sweep]] – swept/*sweeped – swept/*sweeped'' :''[[wikt:upsweep|upsweep]] – upswept/*upsweeped – upswept/*upsweeped'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with vowel shortening |-valign=top |''[[wikt:swell|swell]] – swelled/*swole/*swelt – swollen/swelled'' :''[[wikt:upswell|upswell]] – upswelled/*upswole/*upswelt – upswollen/upswelled'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]], with regularized forms |-valign=top |''[[wikt:swelt|*swelt]] – swelted/*swolt – swelted/*swolten'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] (or regularized). :''[[wikt:foretell|foretell]] – foretold/*foretelled – foretold/*foretelled'' :''[[wikt:forthtell|forthtell]] – forthtold – forthtold'' :''[[wikt:mistell|mistell]] – mistold – mistold'' :''[[wikt:retread|retread]] – retrod/*retread/*retreaded/*retrodden – retrodden/retrod/*retread/*retreaded'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 5|Strong, class 5]] (or regularized) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:vex|vex]] – vexed/*vext – vexed/*vext'' | |-valign=top |''[[wikt:wake|wake]] – woke/*waked – woken/*waked'' :''[[wikt:awake|awake]] – awoke/*awaked – awoken/*awaked'' | [[Germanic strong overweared/overwore – overweared/overworn'' | Originally [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|weak]], fell into a strong pattern by analogy with ''bear'' |-valign=top |''[[wikt:weave|weave]] – wove – woven'' :''[[wikt:interweave|interweave]] – interwove – interwoven'' :''[[wikt:unweave|*unweave]] – unwove – unwoven'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 7|Strong, class 7]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:wed#English|wed]] – wed/wedded – wed/wedded'' :''[[wikt:miswed|miswed]] – miswed/miswedded – miswed/miswedded'' :''[[wikt:rewed#English|rewed]] – rewed/rewedded – rewed/rewedded'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals (or regular) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:weep|weep]] – wept/weeped – wept/weeped'' :''[[wikt:beweep|*beweep]] – bewept/beweeped – bewept/beweeped'' | Originally [[Germanic strong verb#Class 7|strong, class 7]], now [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|weak]] with vowel shortening |-valign=top |''[[wikt:wend|wend]] – wended/*went – wended/*went'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]], once with coalescence of dentals and devoiced ending, but now regular; ''went'' is used as the past of ''[[go (verb)|go]]'' |-valign=top |''[[wikt:wet|wet]] – wet/wetted – wet/wetted'' :''[[wikt:overwet|overwet]] – overwet/overwetted – overwet/overwetted'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]] with coalescence of dentals (or regular) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:will|will]] – would – ''(none) | [[Preterite-present verb|Preterite-present]], [[Defective verb|defective]]. See [[English modal verbs]], and [[Shall and will|''shall'' and ''will'']]. (In non-[[auxiliary verb|auxiliary]] uses the verb is regular.) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:win|win]] – won – won'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:wind|wind]] – wound – wound'' :''[[wikt:rewind|rewind]] – rewound – rewound'' :''[[wikt:unwind|unwind]] – unwound – unwound'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]]. (The identically spelt verb ''wind'' {{IPA|/wɪnd/}}, with meanings connected with air flow and breathlessness, is regular.) |-valign=top |''[[wikt:work|work]] – worked/*wrought – worked/*wrought'' :''[[wikt:overwork|overwork]] – overworked/*overwrought – overworked/*overwrought'' | [[English irregular verbs#Weak verbs|Weak]], now regular, formerly with ''[[Rückumlaut]]'' and [[metathesis (linguistics)|metathesis]] of ''r'' and ''o'' |-valign=top |''[[wikt:worth|*worth]] – worth/worthed – worth/worthed/worthen'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]], or regularized |-valign=top |''[[wikt:wreak|wreak]] – wreaked/*wrought/*wrack/*wroke – wreaked/*wrought/*wreaken/*wroken'' |Weak, usually regular; ''wrought'' (which is in fact from ''work'') has come sometimes to be identified with this verb (perhaps by analogy with ''seek–sought''). Other forms by analogy with strong verbs. |-valign=top |''[[wikt:wring|wring]] – wrang/wrung/*wringed – wrung/*wringed'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 3|Strong, class 3]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:write|write]] – wrote/*writ – written/*writ'' :''[[wikt:cowrite|cowrite]] – cowrote/*writ – cowritten'' :''[[wikt:ghostwrite|ghostwrite]] – ghostwrote/*ghostwrit – ghostwritten/*ghostwrit'' :''[[wikt:handwrite|handwrite]] – handwrote/*handwrit – handwritten/*handwrit'' :''[[wikt:miswrite|miswrite]] – miswrote/*miswrit – miswritten/*miswrit'' :''[[wikt:overwrite|overwrite]] – overwrote/*overwrit – overwritten/*overwrit'' :''[[wikt:rewrite|rewrite]] – rewrote/*rewrit – rewritten/*rewrit'' :''[[wikt:underwrite|underwrite]] – underwrote/*underwrit – underwritten/*underwrit'' |[[Germanic strong verb#Class 1|Strong, class 1]] |-valign=top |''[[wikt:writhe|writhe]] – writhed/*wrothe – writhed/*writhen'' | [[Germanic strong verb#Class 1|Strong, class 1]], now regularized |-valign=top |''[[wikt:zinc|zinc]] – zinced/zinked/zincked – zinced/zinked/zincked'' | |}
==Present tense irregular verbs== {{see also|English irregular verbs#Verbs with irregular present tenses}} Though the list of verbs irregular in the preterite or past participle is long, the list of irregular ''[[present tense]]'' verbs is very short. Excepting [[modal verb]]s like "shall", "will", and "can" that do not inflect at all in the present tense, there are only four (only two if pronunciation is ignored): *[[wiktionary:be|be]]: ''I '''am''', thou '''art''', you '''are''', he '''is''', we '''are''', they '''are'''''. *[[wiktionary:do|do]] (and compounds such as "undo" and "redo"): ''I do, you do, he '''does''', we do, they do'' where "does" is pronounced {{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|ʌ|z}} in contrast to {{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|uː}}, the pronunciation of the infinitive and the other present tense forms. *[[wiktionary:have|have]]: ''I have, you have, he '''has''', we have, they have''. *[[wiktionary:say|say]] (and compounds such as "gainsay" and "naysay"): ''I say, you say, he '''says''', we say, they say'' where "says" has the standard pronunciation {{IPAc-en|s|ɛ|z}} (in contrast to the {{IPAc-en|s|eɪ}} used for the infinitive and other present tense forms).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [[Wiktionary:Category:English irregular verbs|Wiktionary's category of English irregular verbs]] * [http://pasttenses.com/irregular-verbs-list Complete List of 638 English Irregular Verbs] with their forms in different tenses. * [http://thestar.com.my/english/story.asp?file=/2005/9/8/lifefocus/11943482&sec=lifefocus Mind Our English: Strong and weak] by Ralph Berry * [http://www.usingenglish.com/reference/irregular-verbs/ English Irregular Verb List] A comprehensive list of English irregular verbs, including their base form, past simple, past participle, 3rd person singular, and the present participle / gerund. *[http://www.theirregularverbs.com TheIrregularVerbs] All the irregular verbs of the English language. Conjugation, pronunciation, translation and examples. *[http://www.verbbusters.com/vsearch.php verbbusters] Searchable reference of English irregular verbs and cognates, with audio.
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of English Irregular Verbs}} [[Category:English grammar]] [[Category:Linguistics lists|English Irregular Verbs]] [[Category:Lists of English words]]

page.title: List of countries where Arabic is an official language

revision.comment: Wrong math
revision.text:
[[File:Official Language - Arabic - Close 1.png|thumb|450px|right|Nations in which Arabic is an official language (de facto or de jure). Arabic in countries with more than 50% Arabic-speakers is considered a majority language, otherwise it is a minority language. {{legend|#088a4b|Official as majority language}} {{legend|#16c46d|Official as minority language}} {{legend|#045fb4|Co-official as majority language}} {{legend|#5599ff|Co-official as minority language}} {{legend|#ffffff|Not official as minority language}}]] [[Arabic]] and its different [[Varieties of Arabic|dialect]]s are spoken by around 422 million speakers (native and non-native) in the [[Arab world]] as well as in the [[Arab diaspora]] making it one of the five [[List of languages by total number of speakers|most spoken languages in the world]]. Currently, 22 countries are [[Member states of the Arab League|member states]] of the [[Arab League]] (as well as 5 countries were granted an observer status) which was founded in [[Cairo]] in 1945. Arabic is classified as a [[macrolanguage]] comprising 30 modern varieties, including its standard form {{cite web|title=Documentation for ISO 639 identifier: ara|url=http://www-01.sil.org/iso639-3/documentation.asp?id=ara}}. Arabic is the ''[[lingua franca]]'' of people who live in countries of the Arab world as well as of [[Arabs]] who live in the diaspora, particularly in [[Latin America]] (especially [[Arab Brazilians|Brazil]] and [[Arab Argentines|Argentina]]) or [[Arabs in Europe|Western Europe]] (like [[Arabs in France|France]], [[Arabs in Spain|Spain]], [[Arabs in Germany|Germany]] or [[Arabs in Italy|Italy]]). [[Cypriot Arabic]] is an recognized [[minority language]] in the [[Member state of the European Union|EU member state]] [[Cyprus]] and is the only European variety of Arabic within the Arabic [[macrolanguage]] {{cite web|title=Documentation for ISO 639 identifier: ara|url=http://www-01.sil.org/iso639-3/documentation.asp?id=ara}}. [[Maltese language|Maltese]] is the only fully separate standardized language to have originated from an Arabic dialect (the extinct [[Sicilian Arabic]] dialect), with independent literary norms - it has its own [[List of ISO 639-1 codes|language code]] (ml/mlt) that is distinct from that used for the Arabic [[macrolanguage]] (ar/ara) and has no [[diglossia|diglossic]] relationship with [[Standard Arabic]] or [[Classical Arabic]].{{cite book|author1=Robert D Hoberman|title=Morphologies of Asia and Africa , Alan S. Kaye (Ed.), Chapter 13: Maltese Morphology|date=2007| publisher=Eisenbrown|quote=Maltese is the chief exception: Classical or Standard Arabic is irrelevant in the Maltese linguistic community and there is no diglossia.|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gaktTQ8vq28C&pg=PA257&lpg=PA257&dq=robert+d+hoberman+morphologies+of+Asia+and+Africa+Chapter+13&source=bl&ots=g5l67Yg1jh&sig=xKG6ccrdQbPeSXvT6yrMBZyjEfI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4xanIz8zWAhVJb1AKHTcZCmIQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=robert%20d%20hoberman%20morphologies%20of%20Asia%20and%20Africa%20Chapter%2013&f=false}}. It is one of the [[Languages of the European Union|official languages of the EU]]. ==Countries with Arabic as an official language== As of 2018, there are 25 independent nations where [[Arabic]] is an [[official language]]. The following is a list of sovereign states and territories where Arabic is an official or ''[[de facto]]'' official language. {| class="sortable wikitable" |+ Countries where Arabic is an official language !scope="col"|No ! width=200px class="unsortable" | Country ! width=100px | Population ! width=600px | Notes ! width=100px | No. of Arabic SpeakersData taken from https://www.ethnologue.com/ Retrieved 21/03/2016 ! width=100px | % of Arabic SpeakersUsed data taken from https://www.ethnologue.com/ and country population to get percentage. Retrieved 21/03/2016 ! width=130px | Member state of

language || 690,302 || 81.4 || Yes |- | 3. || {{flag|Chad}} || 10,329,208 || Co-official language, along with [[French language|French]] || 1,320,000 || 1.81 || No |- | 4. || {{flag|Comoros}} || language|Tigrinya]] and [[English language|English]] || 249,700 || 3.83 || [[Member states of the Arab League#List of current observer states|Observer status]] |- | 8. || {{flag|Iraq}} || 36,004,552 Out of the 193 [[Member states of the United Nations|member states]] of the [[United Nations]], 136 member states currently [[International recognition of the State of Palestine|recognize the State of Palestine]].
b. The [[Palestinian territories]] (also called [[Israeli-occupied territories]]) are currently occupied by Israel but legally don`t belong to the [[Israel|state of Israel]] according to the [[Supreme Court of Israel]] and the [[International Court of Justice]] of the [[United Nations]] (UN).
c. The [[National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces|Syrian National Coalition]] is partially [[National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces#International recognition|recognized as the sole legitimate government]] of the state [[Syrian opposition|Syrian Arab Republic]].
d. Libya's seat is taken by the [[House of Representatives (Libya)]] (which is disputed by the [[Muslim Brotherhood]]-led [[General National Congress (2014)]] and [[Government of National Accord]]).
e. Syria's seat currently occupied by the [[Syrian National Coalition]],{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/video/2013-04/06/c_132288184.htm|title=Syrian president slams Arab League for granting seat to opposition|date=2013-04-06|accessdate=6 June 2017|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]]}} while [[Ba'ath Party (Syrian-dominated faction)|Ba'athist]] [[Syria|Syrian Arab Republic]] suspended on 16 November 2011.{{cite web|title=Regime backers express anger at other nations after Arab League suspends Syria|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/11/12/world/meast/syria-unrest/index.html?eref=igoogledmn_topstories |author=|accessdate=6 June 2017|website=cnn.com|publisher=CNN|date=2011-11-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.arableagueonline.org/hello-world/#more-1|title=Presentation of the Arab League|date=2012-09-13|accessdate=6 June 2017|publisher=Arableagueonline.org}}
f. Yemen's seat is taken by the [[Cabinet of Yemen]] (which is disputed by the [[Houthi]] [[Supreme Revolutionary Committee]]).
|} ==Countries with Arabic as a national language or a recognized minority language== As of 2016, there are 6 independent nations where Arabic is a [[national language]] or a recognized [[minority language]], but not primary language. The following is a list of sovereign states and territories where Arabic is a national language or a recognized minority language. [[File:Dispersión lengua árabe.png|thumb|Dispersion of native Arabic speakers as the majority (green) or minority (chartreuse) population]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Countries where Arabic is a national language or a recognized minority language ! No ! Country ! Population ! National language or Minority language ! Region |- | 1. || {{flag|Cyprus}} || 1,141,166 || Minority language || [[Asia]] |- | 2. || {{flag|Iran}} || 79,926,270 || Minority language || Asia |- | 3. || {{flag|Mali}} || 14,517,176 || National language || [[Africa]] |- | 4. || {{flag|Niger}} || 18,638,600 || National language || Africa |- | 5. || {{flag|Senegal}} || 14,320,055 || National language || Africa |- | 6. || {{flag|Turkey}} || 79,814,871 || Minority language || Asia, [[Europe]] |- | '''Σ 6''' || '''Total''' || '''Σ 210,000,000''' || || |} ===Cyprus=== {{Also|Languages of Cyprus}} [[Cypriot Arabic]] (alongside [[Armenian language|Armenian]]) is one of the two recognized minority languages of [[Cyprus]], since 2008.{{cite web|url=http://languagecharter.eokik.hu/sites/StatesParties/Cyprus.htm|title=Implementation of the Charter in Cyprus|website=Database for the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages|publisher=Public Foundation for European Comparative Minority Research|accessdate=24 December 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111024143749/http://languagecharter.eokik.hu/sites/StatesParties/Cyprus.htm|archivedate=24 October 2011|df=}} It is spoken by the [[Maronite Cypriots|Maronite]] community, which is a [[Demographics of Cyprus|minority in Cyprus]] especially in the cities [[Nicosia]], [[Limassol]] and [[Larnaca]]. Cypriot Arabic (also known as Cypriot Maronite Arabic) is taught at the [[Elementary School of St. Maron]], which is located in [[Anthoupolis]] southern of Nicosia, Cyprus.[[Maronite Community of Cyprus]]: [http://www.maronitesofcyprus.com/cgibin/hweb282f.html?-A=802&-V=schools ''St Maron Elementary School''], 11 December 2013, Retrieved 15 January 2018. ===Iran=== {{Also|Languages of Iran}} Arabic is a recognized minority language of [[Iran]]. In addition, the constitution recognizes the Arabic language as the language of Islam, giving it a formal status as the language of religion, and regulates its spreading within the Iranian national curriculum. After the [[Iranian Revolution|Islamic Revolution]] in 1979, Arabic (as the language of [[Quran]]) became mandatory for pupils in Iran. Arabic courses are mandatory starting from 6th year of schooling (1st year of Middle School) until the 11th year (penultimate year of High School). The local [[varieties of Arabic|dialects of Arabic]] spoken by [[Iranian Arabs|Arab minorities in Iran]] (like [[Ahwazi Arabs]], [[Khamseh Arabs]], [[Marsh Arabs]] as well as [[Arabs in Khorasan]]) are [[Khuzestani Arabic]] and [[Mesopotamian Arabic]], (also known as Iraqi Arabic) mainly in [[Khuzestan Province]] as well as [[Khorasani Arabic]] especially in [[Khorasan Province]]. There are several TV channels in Arabic language broadcasting from Iran, namely, [[Al-Alam News Network|Al-Alam]], [[Al-Kawthar TV]] as well as [[iFilm (TV channel)|IFilm]]. Currently, the sole [[List of Arab newspapers|newspaper in Arabic language]] published in Iran is [[Kayhan Al Arabi]] out of 23 Persian dailies and three English dailies [[List of newspapers in Iran|newspapers in Iran]]. In 2008, the public university [[Payame Noor University]] declared that Arabic will be the "second language" of the university, and that all its services will be offered in Arabic, concurrent with [[Persian language|Persian]].{{cite news|url=http://radiozamaaneh.com/news/2008/03/post_4081.html|script-title=fa:عربی دومین زبان دانشگاه پیام نور شد|language=Persian|publisher=Radiozamaaneh.com|accessdate= 30 December 2017}} ===Mali=== {{Also|Languages of Mali}} Arabic is one of the recognized national languages in [[Mali]]. [[Hassaniya Arabic]] (a variety of [[Maghrebi Arabic]]) is spoken by a [[Demographics of Mali|minority in Mali]] especially by the [[Azawagh Arabs]] (also known as nomadic [[Moors]]) nomadic [[ethnic]] [[Arabs|Arab]]-ancestry tribes who are settling mainly in the area of [[Azawagh]] which is a dry [[structural basin|basin]] covering what is today northwestern [[Niger]], as well as parts of northeastern [[Mali]] and southern [[Algeria]].Paris (1995): p. 250. ===Niger=== {{Also|Languages of Niger}} Arabic is one of the recognized national languages in [[Niger]]. Arabic is spoken by a [[Demographics of Niger|minority in Niger]] especially by the [[Diffa Arabs]] (also known as Mahamid Arabs) an Arab nomadic tribespeople who is living in eastern Niger, mostly in the [[Diffa Region]]. ===Senegal=== {{Also|Languages of Senegal}} Arabic is one of the recognized national languages in [[Senegal]]. Hassaniya Arabic is spoken by a [[Demographics of Senegal|minority in Senegal]].[[Ethnologue]]: [https://www.ethnologue.com/country/SN/languages ''Ethnologue Languages of the World – Senegal - Languages''], Retrieved 31 December 2017. ===Turkey=== {{Also|Languages of Turkey}} There is an [[Arabs in Turkey|Arab minority in Turkey]] who speak Arabic as their native language. Therefore, Arabic is a recognized minority language in [[Turkey]]. Historically Arabic was the official language (in the territory which form nowadays the state of Turkey) during the time when this [[History of Anatolia#Arab conquests and threats|region was a part of]] the [[Umayyad Caliphate]] between 661 and 750 and later when it [[Arab–Byzantine wars#Raids under the last Umayyads and the rise of Iconoclasm|belonged to]] the [[Abbasid Caliphate]] (750–1258). The national public broadcaster of Turkey the [[Turkish Radio and Television Corporation]] (also known as TRT) broadcasts [[TRT Al Arabiya]] a 24 hours a day TV channel in Arabic language (launched in April 2010). In 2015, the [[Ministry of National Education (Turkey)|Turkey’s Ministry of Education]] announced that as of the 2016-17 academic year, Arabic language courses (as a second language) will be offered to students in elementary school starting in second grade. The Arabic courses will be offered as an elective language course like [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]] and [[English language|English]] which are already being offered to elementary school students for a long time. According to a prepared curriculum, second and third graders will start learning the Arabic language by listening-comprehension and speaking, while introduction to writing will join these skills in fourth grade and after fifth grade students will start learning the language in all its four basic skills.[[Al-Monitor]]: [https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/11/turkey-arabic-education-divides-country.html ''Turks divided over plans to introduce Arabic-language teaching''], 2 November 2015, Retrieved 29 December 2017.[[Hürriyet Daily News]]: [http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/arabic-to-be-offered-as-second-language-in-turkish-elementary-schools--90244 ''Arabic to be offered as second language in Turkish elementary schools''], 23 October 2015, Retrieved 29 December 2017. ==Countries where Arabic has a special status according to the constitution== As of 2018, there are 4 independent countries where Arabic has a special status according to the constitution. The following is a list of sovereign states and territories where Arabic has a special status according to the constitution. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Countries where Arabic has a special status according to the constitution ! No ! Name ! Population ! Official recognized
language ! Region |- | 1. || {{flag|Iran}} || 79,926,270 || Arabic a || Asia |- | 2. || {{flag|Israel}} b || 8,238,300 || Arabic c || Asia |- | 3. || {{flag|Pakistan}} || 212,742,631 || Arabic d || Asia |- | 4. || {{flag|Philippines}} || 100,981,437 || Arabic e || Asia |- | '''Σ 4''' || '''Total''' || '''Σ 400,000,000''' || || |- class="sortbottom" | colspan = "7" |a. {{note|a}} The constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran recognizes the Arabic language as the language of Islam, giving it a formal status as the language of religion, and regulates its spreading within the Iranian national curriculum. The constitution declares in Chapter II: (The Official Language, Script, Calendar, and Flag of the Country) in Article 16 "Since the language of the Qur`an and Islamic texts and teachings is Arabic, ..., it must be taught after elementary level, in all classes of secondary school and in all areas of study."[[Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran]]: [https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Iran_1989?lang=en ''Iran (Islamic Republic of)`s Constitution of 1979. - Article: 16 Official or national languages''], 1979, retrieved 25 July 2018
b. Out of the 193 [[Member states of the United Nations|member states]] of the [[United Nations]], 161 member states currently [[International recognition of Israel|recognize the State of Israel]].
c. {{note|c}} The [[Basic Law: Israel as the Nation-State of the Jewish People]] (an [[Basic Laws of Israel|Israeli Basic Law]] which specifies the nature of the [[State of Israel]] as the [[nation-state]] of the [[Jewish People]]) states in No. 4 (B) that "The Arabic language has a special status in the state; Regulating the use of Arabic in state institutions or by them will be set in law." The law declares in No. 4 (C): "This clause does not harm the status given to the Arabic language before this law came into effect." The law was adopted by the [[Knesset]] 62 in favor, 55 against and two abstentions on 19 July 2018.{{cite web |title=Full text of Basic Law: Israel as the Nation State of the Jewish People |url=https://knesset.gov.il/spokesman/eng/PR_eng.asp?PRID=13978 |website=The Knesset: Press Releases |publisher=State of Israel |accessdate=20 July 2018}}
d. {{note|d}} The constitution of Pakistan states in Article 31 No. 2 that "The State shall endeavour, as respects the Muslims of Pakistan (a) to make the teaching of the Holy Quran and Islamiat compulsory, to encourage and facilitate the learning of Arabic language ..."[[Constitution of Pakistan]]: [https://pakistanconstitutionlaw.com/article-31-islamic-way-of-life ''Constitution of Pakistan, 1973 - Article: 31 Islamic way of life''], 1973, retrieved 13 June 2018
e. {{note|e}} The 1987 Philippine constitution specifies "Spanish and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis."{{cite web|author1=Joselito Guianan Chan |author2=Managing Partner |url=http://www.chanrobles.com/article14language.htm |title=1987 Constitution of the Republic of the Philippines, Article XIV, Section 7.|publisher=Chan Robles & Associates Law Firm |accessdate=June 13, 2018}}
|} ===Iran=== {{Also|Languages of Iran}} The [[Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran|constitution]] of the [[Iran|Islamic Republic of Iran]] recognizes the Arabic language as the language of Islam, giving it a formal status as the language of religion, and regulates its spreading within the Iranian national curriculum. The constitution declares in Chapter II: (The Official Language, Script, Calendar, and Flag of the Country) in Article 16 "''Since the language of the Qur`an and Islamic texts and teachings is Arabic, ..., it must be taught after elementary level, in all classes of secondary school and in all areas of study.''"[[Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran]]: [https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Iran_1989?lang=en ''Iran (Islamic Republic of)`s Constitution of 1979. - Article: 16 Official or national languages''], 1979, retrieved 25 July 2018 ===Israel=== {{Also|Languages of Israel}} Historically Arabic was the official language (in the territory which form nowadays the [[State of Israel]]) for around 1,382 years from 636 until 2018. The [[Knesset]] canceled Arabic as an official language and gave Arabic a special status of the country Israel by adopting the relevant Basic Law. The [[Basic Law: Israel as the Nation-State of the Jewish People]] (an [[Basic Laws of Israel|Israeli Basic Law]] which specifies the nature of the State of Israel as the [[nation-state]] of the [[Jewish People]]) states in No. 4 (B) that "''The Arabic language has a special status in the state; Regulating the use of Arabic in state institutions or by them will be set in law.''" The law declares in No. 4 (C): "''This clause does not harm the status given to the Arabic language before this law came into effect.''" The law was adopted by the [[Knesset]] 62 in favor, 55 against and two abstentions on 19 July 2018.{{cite web |title=Full text of Basic Law: Israel as the Nation State of the Jewish People |url=https://knesset.gov.il/spokesman/eng/PR_eng.asp?PRID=13978 |website=The Knesset: Press Releases |publisher=State of Israel |accessdate=20 July 2018}} Arabic is an [[indigenous language]] in the territory which form nowadays the state of Israel and which is still the [[lingua franca]] of [[Arab citizens of Israel]] as well as of [[Arabs|Arab foreigners]] (especially [[Palestinians]] who have only a [[Palestinian Authority passport]] which is not recognized of many countries as these countries don`t recognize the State of Palestine why these Palestinians are seen as [[statelessness]] of many countries). In addition, Arabic is spoken of Arab Jews in Israel who [[Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries|immigrated from different Arab countries to Israel]] (as [[Aliyah]]) and got the [[Israeli nationality law|Israeli citizenship]] according to the [[Israeli Nationality Law of 1952]]. ===Pakistan=== {{Also|Languages of Pakistan}} Historically Arabic was the official language (in the territory which form nowadays the state [[Islamic Republic of Pakistan]]) during the time when this [[History of Pakistan#Arab Caliphate|region was a part of]] the [[Umayyad Caliphate]] between 651 and 750. According to the [[Constitution of Pakistan of 1956]] the two languages [[Urdu]] (which is very close to [[Hindi]], both also called [[Hindustani language]] which were two of the ''[[lingua franca]]'' of [[North India]] and [[Pakistan]] that time{{Citation | title=Hindustani-English code-mixing in modern literary texts | author=Mohammad Tahsin Siddiqi | year=1994 | isbn= | publisher=University of Wisconsin | url=https://books.google.com/?id=vnrTAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... Hindustani is the lingua franca of both India and Pakistan ...''}}{{Citation | title=World Regional Geography: Global Patterns, Local Lives |author1=Lydia Mihelič Pulsipher |author2=Alex Pulsipher |author3=Holly M. Hapke | year=2005 | isbn=0-7167-1904-5 | publisher=Macmillan | url=https://books.google.com/?id=WfNaSNNAppQC | quote=''... By the time of British colonialism, Hindustani was the lingua franca of all of northern India and what is today Pakistan ...''}}) as well as [[Bengali language|Bengali]] (at that time the lingua franca in the territory which is today the independent state [[Bangladesh]]) became the national languages in the new founded state Islamic Republic of Pakistan. General [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)|Ayub Khan]] the second [[List of Presidents of Pakistan|President of Pakistan]] advocated the institution of Arabic language teaching a spart of national planning.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.de/books?id=FddJQi1dQ30C&pg=PA40&lpg=PA40&dq=Arabic+language+Muhammad+Zia-ul-Haq&source=bl&ots=oCDAuXSrnQ&sig=yP7jQVHxCauF8e9vk2XHeamm2r0&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjP-cmfuN3bAhVKJ1AKHaEMA1E4ChDoAQg4MAM#v=onepage&q=Arabic%20language%20Muhammad%20Zia-ul-Haq&f=false |title= Speaking Like a State, Language and Nationalism in Pakistan |last=Ayres |first=Alyssa |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-521-51931-1 |location=New York, USA |page=39 |quote=General Ayub Khan was the first Pakistani leader to advocate the institution of Arabic language teaching as part of national planning.}} "Ayub`s educational plan emphasized Urdu and English as the primary language of Pakistan, but additionally recommended that Arabic be a secondary language of instruction along with English."{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.de/books?id=FddJQi1dQ30C&pg=PA40&lpg=PA40&dq=Arabic+language+Muhammad+Zia-ul-Haq&source=bl&ots=oCDAuXSrnQ&sig=yP7jQVHxCauF8e9vk2XHeamm2r0&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjP-cmfuN3bAhVKJ1AKHaEMA1E4ChDoAQg4MAM#v=onepage&q=Arabic%20language%20Muhammad%20Zia-ul-Haq&f=false |title= Speaking Like a State, Language and Nationalism in Pakistan |last=Ayres |first=Alyssa |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-521-51931-1 |location=New York, USA |pages=39, 40 |quote=Ayub`s educational plan emphasized Urdu and English as the primary language of Pakistan, but additionally recommended that Arabic be a secondary language of instruction along with English.}} The Arabic language is mentioned in the [[Constitution of Pakistan|constitution of Pakistan]]. It declares in article 31 No. 2 that ''"The State shall endeavour, as respects the [[Muslim]]s of [[Pakistan]] (a) to make the teaching of the [[Quran|Holy Quran]] and [[Islamic studies|Islamiat]] compulsory, to encourage and facilitate the learning of Arabic language ..."''[[Constitution of Pakistan]]: [https://pakistanconstitutionlaw.com/article-31-islamic-way-of-life ''Constitution of Pakistan, 1973 - Article: 31 Islamic way of life''], 1973, retrieved 13 June 2018 There is also an [[Arabs in Pakistan|Arab minority in Pakistan]]. In addition, a remarkable number of [[Pakistanis]] are able to speak Arabic as they were living in the rich [[Gulf Cooperation Council|GCC Countries]] for working reasons (in [[Pakistanis in Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabia]] around 2.5 million; in [[Pakistanis in the United Arab Emirates|UAE]] around 1.5 million; in [[Pakistanis in Qatar|Qatar]] around 650,000; in [[Pakistanis in Kuwait|Kuwait]] around 430,000; in [[Pakistanis in Oman|Oman]] around 300,000; in [[Pakistanis in Bahrain|Bahrain]] around 180,000) for a very long time. These [[overseas Pakistani]]s who are living in countries of the [[Arab world]] are also named [[Pakistanis|Arab Pakistanis or Pakistani Arabs]]. The National Education Policy 2017 declares in article 3.7.4 that: “''Arabic as compulsory part will be integrated in Islamiyat from Middle to Higher Secondary level to enable the students to understand the Holy Quran.''“ Furthermore, it specifies in article 3.7.6: “''Arabic as elective subject shall be offered properly at Secondary and Higher Secondary level with Arabic literature and grammar in its course to enable the learners to have command in the language.''“ This law is also valid for private schools as it defines in article 3.7.12: “''The curriculum in Islamiyat, Arabic and Moral Education of public sector will be adopted by the private institutions to make uniformity in the society.''“[[Ministry of Federal Education and Professional Training]]: [http://www.moent.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/National%20Educaiton%20Policy%202017.pdf ''National Education Policy 2017''], p. 25, retrieved 19 June 2018 ===Philippines=== {{Also|Languages of the Philippines}} The Arabic language is mentioned in the [[Philippine Constitutional Commission of 1986|Philippine constitution of 1986]]. It specifies that ''"Spanish and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis."''{{cite web|author1=Joselito Guianan Chan |author2=Managing Partner |url=http://www.chanrobles.com/article14language.htm |title=1987 Constitution of the Republic of the Philippines, Article XIV, Section 7.|publisher=Chan Robles & Associates Law Firm |accessdate=June 13, 2018}} Arabic is mainly used by some [[Islam in the Philippines|Filipino Muslim]]s in both a [[liturgical language|liturgical]] and instructional capacity since the arrival of [[Islam in the Philippines|Islam]] and establishment of several [[Sultan|Sultanates]] (like [[Sultanate of Maguindanao]], [[Sultanate of Sulu]] and [[Confederation of sultanates in Lanao|Sultanate of Ranaw]]) in the present-day state [[Philippines]]. Along with [[Malay language|Malay]], Arabic was the ''[[lingua franca]]'' of the [[Malay Archipelago]] among Muslim traders and the Malay [[aristocracy]] in the [[History of the Philippines|history]]. Arabic is taught for free and is promoted in some Islamic centres predominantly in the [[Mindanao|southernmost parts of Philippines]]. ==Non-sovereign entities where Arabic is an official language== As of 2016, there are 9 non-sovereign entities where Arabic is an official language. The following is a list of [[List of states with limited recognition|non-sovereign entities]] and [[autonomous region]]s as well as [[Territory|territories]] where Arabic is an official or ''de facto'' official language. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Non-sovereign entities and territories where Arabic is an official or de facto official language ! No ! Name ! Population ! Notes ! Region |- | 1. || {{flag|Azawad}} || 1,300,000 || Co-official language, along with [[Tuareg languages|Tuareg]] || Africa |- | 2. || {{flag|Iraqi Kurdistan}} || 5,300,000 || Co-official language, along with [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]] || Asia |- | 3. || {{flag|Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} || 4,800,000 || Official language || Asia |- | 4. || {{flag|Khatumo}} || 1,000,000 || Co-official language, along with [[Somali language|Somali]] || Africa |- | 5. || {{flag|Puntland}} || 4,280,000 || Co-official language, along with Somali || Africa |- | 6. || {{flag|Rojava}} (also called Democratic Federation of Northern Syria) || 4,600,000 || Co-official language, along with Kurdish and [[Syriac language|Syriac]] || Asia |- | 7. || {{flag|Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic}} || 502,585 || Co-official language, along with [[Spanish language|Spanish]] || Africa |- | 8. || {{flag|Somaliland}} || 4,500,000 || Co-official language, along with Somali || Africa |- | 9. || {{flag|Syrian opposition}} a || 3,500,000 || Official language || Asia |- | '''Σ 9''' || '''Total''' || '''Σ 30,000,000''' || || |- class="sortbottom" | colspan = "7" | a. The [[National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces|Syrian National Coalition]] is partially [[National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces#International recognition|recognized as the sole legitimate government]] of the state [[Syrian opposition|Syrian Arab Republic]].
|} ==History== {{Main article| Arab world#History}} ===Umayyad Caliphate=== [[File:Map of expansion of Caliphate.svg|350px|thumb|right|The expansion of the first [[Caliphate]]s: {{legend|#a1584e|Expansion under [[prophets and messengers in Islam|Islamic prophet]] [[Constitution of Medina|Muhammad]],
622–632 [[Gregorian calendar|AD]]/ 1-11 [[Hijri year|AH]]}} {{legend|#ef9070|Expansion during the [[Rashidun Caliphate]],
632–661 AD/ 11-40 AH}} {{legend|#fad07d|Expansion during the [[Umayyad Caliphate]],
661–750 AD/ 40-129 AH}}]] The [[Early Muslim conquests|early Muslim conquests]] ({{lang-ar|الفتوحات الإسلامية}}, '''al-Futūḥāt al-Islāmiyya''') and the following [[Spread of Islam|Expansion of Islam]] ({{lang-ar|انتشار الإسلام}}, '''Intishar al-Islām''') led to the [[Arabization|expansion of the Arabic language]] in [[North Africa|Northern Africa]], the [[Iberian Peninsula]], the [[Caucasus]], [[Western Asia]], [[Central Asia]] and [[South Asia]]. Along with the [[Islam|religion of Islam]], the Arabic language, [[Arabic numerals|Arabic number system]] and Arab customs spread throughout the entire Arab [[caliphate]]. The [[caliph]]s of the Arab dynasty established the first schools inside the empire which taught Arabic language and [[Islamic studies]] for all pupils in all areas within the caliphate. The result was (in those areas which belonged to the Arab empire) the creation of the society that was mostly Arabic-speaking because of the assimilation of native inhabitants. During the period of the [[Umayyad Caliphate]] (661–750), the 5th [[Umayyad]] [[caliph]] [[Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan|Abd al-Malik]] (646–705) established Arabic instead of the local languages as the sole official [[Official language|state language]] of government across the entire caliphate.{{cite encyclopedia|last= |first= |authorlink= |editor-first= |editor-last= |editor-link= |encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica|title='Abd al-Malik|edition=15th |year=2010| publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.|volume=I: A-Ak - Bayes|location= Chicago, Illinois|isbn=978-1-59339-837-8|pages=14–15}} ===Abbasid Caliphate=== While the [[Abbasid Caliphate]] (750–1258) originally gained power by exploiting the social inequalities against non-[[Arab]]s in the [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad Empire]], during Abbasid rule the empire rapidly was [[Arabization|Arabized]]. As knowledge was shared in the Arabic language throughout the empire, people of different nationalities and religions began gradually to speak Arabic in their everyday lives. Resources from other languages began to be translated into Arabic, and a unique Islamic identity began to form that fused previous cultures with Arab culture, creating a level of [[civilization]] and knowledge that was considered a marvel in [[Europe]] and the [[Western world]].{{harvnb|Ochsenwald|Fisher|2004|p=69}} ===Fatimid Caliphate=== The Arabic language remained the [[lingua franca]] of high culture under the [[Fatimid Caliphate|Fatimids]] (909–1171), [[Caliphate of Córdoba|Spanish Umayyads]] (856–1031) in the [[Iberian Peninsula]], and later [[List of Muslim states and dynasties|Muslim dynasties]] in [[North Africa]] and [[Spain]] and of the [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluks]] (1250–1517) in [[Egypt Eyalet|Egypt]] and [[Levant|Syria-Palestine]].Hayrettin Yücesoy (2015) “[https://www.academia.edu/17004690/Language_of_Empire_Politics_of_Arabic_and_Persian_in_the_Abbasid_World ''Language of Empire: Politics of Arabic and Persian in the Abbasid World''], p. 388. ===Al-Andalus=== In the history, [[Andalusian Arabic]] was the official language in [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]], formerly [[Al-Andalus]] for more than 700 years until the [[fall of Granada|fall of the last Islamic state in Iberia at Granada]] in 1492. ===Italy and Malta=== [[Siculo-Arabic]] (or Sicilian Arabic) was a spoken language on the islands of [[Sicily]] and neighbouring [[Malta]] (at that time [[Emirate of Sicily]] (831–1091)) between the end of the ninth century and the end of the twelfth century. ===Greece=== Furthermore, a form of Arabic was spoken on the [[Mediterranean]] [[island]] of [[Crete]] (in those days [[Emirate of Crete]]) from the late 820s (c. 824 or 827/828) until the [[Siege of Chandax|Byzantine reconquest]] in 961. ===South Sudan=== Arabic (alongside English) was an official language in [[South Sudan]] from 1863 (these days a part of [[Egypt Eyalet]] (1517–1867)) until 2011 (that time the independent state [[South Sudan|Republic of South Sudan]]), when the former government canceled Arabic as an official language. Since 2011 English is the sole official language of South Sudan. The Arabic dialect [[Juba Arabic]] is still the [[lingua franca]] of the people in South Sudan. ===The Gambia=== In 2014, Gambian [[President of the Gambia|president]] [[Yahya Jammeh]] announced that [[The Gambia]] would drop English as the official language because it is a "colonial relic".[[Al-Jazeera]]: [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2014/03/gambia-drop-english-as-colonial-relic-2014313141814734996.html "Gambia to drop English as 'colonial relic'"] 13 March 2014, Retrieved 12 July 2018.[[Index on Censorship]]: [https://www.indexoncensorship.org/2014/03/gambia-language ''Gambia’s president wants to ditch English as official language''], 28 March 2014, retrieved 12 July 2018 He replaced Gambia’s official language English with Arabic in 2014.[[France 24]]: [http://www.france24.com/en/20170111-gambia-profile-president-yahya-jammeh-proud-dictator "Gambia’s Yahya Jammeh, a dictator and ‘proud’ of it"] 11 January 2017, Retrieved 12 July 2018. However, such change was not enacted. ===Israel=== Historically Arabic was the official language (in the territory which form nowadays the [[Israel|State of Israel]]) for around 1,382 years. The Arabic language was spread with the [[Muslim conquest of the Levant]] (which took place between 634 and 638) and became the official language in the territory of [[Jund Filastin]] (which was a part of the [[Rashidun Caliphate]] at that time). Arabic remained as the official language in this area during the time of different [[List of Sunni Muslim dynasties|Muslim dynasties]] which control this territory for several centuries, namely [[Umayyad Caliphate]], [[Abbasid Caliphate]], [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluk Sultanate]], [[Damascus Eyalet]] (an [[eyalet]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]]), [[Syria Vilayet]] (a first-level administrative division ([[vilayet]]) of the Ottoman Empire), [[Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem]] (an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] district with special administrative status) as well as during the time when this territory came under the control of the [[British Empire]] (known as [[Occupied Enemy Territory Administration]]) and the following geopolitical entity [[Mandatory Palestine]]. The Arabic language (alongside [[Modern Hebrew|Hebrew]]) also remained as an official language in the State of Israel for the first 70 years after the proclamation in 1948 until 2018. The [[Knesset]] canceled the status of Arabic as an official language by adopting the relevant [[Basic Law: Israel as the Nation-State of the Jewish People]] on 19 July 2018. This [[Basic Laws of Israel|Israeli Basic Law]] states in No. 4 (A) that "''The state’s language is Hebrew.''"{{cite web |title=Full text of Basic Law: Israel as the Nation State of the Jewish People |url=https://knesset.gov.il/spokesman/eng/PR_eng.asp?PRID=13978 |website=The Knesset: Press Releases |publisher=State of Israel |accessdate=20 July 2018}} ==Territories where Arabic was an official or de facto official language and later replaced or repealed== There were several territories (which later became independent states) where Arabic was an official or ''de facto'' official language and where it has been replaced by other languages or repealed. The following is a list of territories (which later became independent states) where Arabic was an official or ''de facto'' official language in the history. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Territories where Arabic was an official or de facto official language and later replaced or repealed ! {{About|the Romance dialect spoken in the Lorraine region of France|the Germanic dialect spoken in northern Lorraine|Lorraine Franconian}} {{Infobox language |name=Lorrain |nativename=''Gaumais'' |region=Northeastern [[France]], [[Belgium]] |speakers=? |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Italic languages|Italic]] |fam3=[[Romance languages|Romance]] |fam4=[[Western Romance|Western]] |fam5=[[Gallo-Romance languages|Gallo-Romance]] |fam6=[[Langues d'oïl|Oïl]] |dia1=[[Welche]] |isoexception=dialect |glotto=lorr1242 |glottorefname=Lorraine |map=Langues d'oïl.PNG |mapcaption=Lorrain, at the east among other [[langues d'oïl|''oïl'' languages]] }} {{Lorraine sidebar}} '''Lorrain''' is a dialect (often referred to as [[patois]]) spoken by a minority of people in [[Lorraine (region)|Lorraine]] in [[France]], small parts of [[Alsace]] and in [[Gaume]] in Belgium. It is a [[langue d'oïl]].
It is classified as a [[languages of France|regional language of France]] and has the recognised status of a regional language of [[Wallonia]], where it is known as '''Gaumais'''. It has been influenced by [[Lorraine Franconian]] and [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]], Germanic languages spoken in nearby or overlapping areas.
==See also== * [[Ban de la Roche]]
==External links== * http://www.travelphrases.info/languages/lorrain.htm * {{fr icon}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=-QoGAAAAQAAJ Essai sur le patois lorrain des environs du comté du Ban de la Roche], Jeremias Jacob Oberlin, 1775
{{Languages of Belgium}} {{Languages of the Benelux}} {{Romance languages}} {{Lorraine topics}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lorrain Language}} [[Category:Oïl languages]] [[Category:Languages of France]] [[Category:Languages of Belgium]] [[Category:Walloon culture]] [[Category:Luxembourg (Belgium)]]

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=March 2009}} {{Infobox comics creator | name = Luiz Eduardo de Oliveira | image = LEO mollat2013.jpg | birth_name = | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1944|12|13}} | birth_place = | death_place = | nationality = [[Brazil]]ian | cartoonist = | write = y | art = y | pencil = | ink = | edit = | publish = | letter = | color = | alias = Léo | notable works = | awards = | website = | subcat = Brazilian }} '''Luiz Eduardo de Oliveira''' (born December 13, 1944),<ref name="Lambiek">{{cite web|url=http://lambiek.net/artists/l/leo.htm|title=Leo|publisher=Lambiek's Comiclopedia|accessdate=27 January 2010}}</ref> more famous under his pen name '''Léo''' is a [[Brazil]]ian [[comics]] creator.
==Biography== After graduating as a mechanical engineer, Oliveira left Brazil because of the then [[Brazilian military government|military dictatorship]]. He lived in [[Chile]] until the [[Chilean coup of 1973]], then in [[Argentina]], before returning to Brazil in 1974. He worked as an illustrator in the advertising industry in [[São Paulo]] before once more leaving Brazil, this time for France, in 1981. He had hoped to find work illustrating comics, but the [[Franco-Belgian comics]] industry was in difficulty at the time so he fell back on advertising once again, with a few comics pieces being published in [[L'Écho des savanes]] and [[Pilote]].
In 1986, with the assistance of [[Jean-Claude Forest]], Oliveira began contributing to the youth oriented magazines of [[Bayard Presse]]. He illustrated true stories for {{Ill|Okapi (magazine){{!}}Okapi|fr|3=Okapi (magazine)}} magazine. He then recounted [[Mahatma Gandhi]]'s life in the album ''Gandhi, le pèlerin de la paix'', for {{Ill|Astrapi|fr}}. In 1988, he began illustrating the stories of the comics writer {{Ill|Rodolphe (author){{!}}Rodolphe|fr|3=Rodolphe (auteur)}}. The collaboration proved fruitful, producing eight albums in the series ''Trent'' and five of another series, ''Kenya''.
In 1993, Oliveira finally achieved a dream when [[Dargaud]] agreed to publish his first solo (writer-artist) series: ''Aldébaran''. This story has continued in the sequel series ''Bételgeuse'' and ''Antarès'', the former nominated for the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival Prize for a Series|Prize for a Series]] at the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival]] in 2004.
==Bibliography== ;Le Pèlerin de la Paix Script by [[Benoît Marchon]], artwork by Léo; [[Éditions du Centurion]] #''Gandhi, le Pèlerin de la Paix'' - (''Gandhi, the Pilgrim of Peace'') (1989)

==Awards== * 2004: nominated for Best International Series at the [[Prix Saint-Michel]], [[Belgium]] :: - nominated for the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival Prix Jeunesse 9-12 ans|Youth Award (9-12 years)]] and the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival Prize for a Series|Series Award]] at the [[Angoulême International Comics Festival]], [[France]]
